terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Colombian mountains near Medellín. Significant elevation with mountain scenery at moderate altitude.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Colombian event. Mountainous terrain with difficult access, high costs, moderate altitude, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Medellín is a regional event in Colombia—mountainous terrain with significant elevation at moderate altitude. The Colombian mountains are impressive, but the difficult/expensive access, altitude, and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A scenic Colombian mountain gravel race with altitude challenge. Worth it for adventure seekers with big budgets. Not practical for most riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you have a big budget and want a Colombian experience—maybe. For most riders—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Colombian terrain: Gravel Bogotá.

logistics.food: Medellín has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Moderate altitude (5000+ feet) requires altitude adaptation.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with mountainous terrain at altitude.

logistics.explanation: Route and start location still unconfirmed for a race six months away shows concerning organizational gaps. International bike travel, Colombian customs, and local transportation create multiple failure points. Being inaugural means zero proven systems for packet pickup, parking, or basic race day logistics.

length.explanation: 120km hits the sweet spot for most riders—long enough to matter, manageable enough to finish strong. Tour operators in the region describe stages ranging from moderate 60km efforts to queen stages packing "a leg-sapping 2,500m of elevation into just 55km of riding." Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Described as moderate terrain with rolling short steep hills and sustained climbs rather than technical rock gardens. Regional routes "climb high into the mountains on a mix of gravel & paved roads," suggesting more fitness test than bike handling challenge through Colombian Andes terrain. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: 7,500 feet of climbing over 75 miles creates substantial suffering without being soul-crushing. Regional tours feature queen stages with "a leg-sapping 2,500m of elevation into just 55km of riding" at altitudes reaching 2,500m, indicating serious vertical challenges ahead. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: August racing in Medellín means the "City of Eternal Spring" delivers mild year-round temperatures of 18-28°C thanks to Andean elevation. The timing coincides with Feria de las Flores featuring parades, music, and traditional 'silletas' flower displays throughout the city. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting at approximately 1,495m above sea level with climbs pushing higher into thin air territory around 2,500m elevation. Enough altitude to notice if you're coming from sea level, but not the oxygen-starved suffering of true high-altitude racing in the Colombian Andes. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

adventure.explanation: Racing through "coffee-scented mountains of the Western Colombian Andes" with routes passing "through Colombian coffee plantations & taste the best coffee in the world at its source." The setting combines Medellín's transformation from cartel capital to cycling mecca with serious mountain consequence.

prestige.explanation: New UCI Gravel World Series qualifier organized by the same team behind established UCI events in Brazil, Chile, and Bogotá suggests competent execution. Top 25% qualify for 2026 Worlds in Australia, but being one of 45 global qualifiers dilutes exclusivity factor considerably.

race_quality.explanation: Route and departure location still unconfirmed as of current intel, which doesn't inspire confidence in organizational readiness. The UCI backing suggests minimum standards, but plenty of sanctioned races still suck in execution.

experience.explanation: Racing gravel in the transformed city once "associated with conflict and cartels" now positioned as "hub of innovation, culture, and urban development" creates compelling narrative. Attractions like Comuna 13's street art tours and Guatapé's colorful lakeside setting add cultural depth beyond the racing.

community.explanation: Colombia's cycling culture runs deeper than most destinations, with the region described as "filled with brightly colored towns and enchanting landscapes" perfect for bike discovery. Being new means no established rider traditions, but the local cycling obsession provides solid foundation.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, new race in expensive international destination means small, self-selected field of adventure seekers rather than deep competitive talent. Colombian climbers will excel on the elevation sections, but overall field size and competitive depth remain complete unknowns for the inaugural edition. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: 120km through Colombian Andes with Worlds qualification potential plus access to Plaza Botero sculptures and Parque Arví nature reserve delivers solid racing-plus-tourism value. Registration costs remain unannounced, but the cultural immersion adds substance beyond just the race itself.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $100-150. International flights to José María Córdova Airport, Colombian accommodations, and logistics for getting your bike there safely will demolish your wallet. Even if registration stays reasonable, the total trip cost puts this firmly in expensive adventure category rather than accessible racing. More expensive than Atlas Mountain Race.

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
